headline: Gramma's Date Squares
description: The best recipe for delicious date squares with buttery layers of goodness and a chewy oatmeal crust. The whole family will love this sweet treat.
name: Gramma's Date Squares

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Combine oats, pastry flour, 1 cup brown sugar, baking soda, and salt in a large bowl. Mix in butter until crumbly. Press half of the mixture into the bottom of a 9-inch square baking pan.

Combine dates, water, and remaining 1/3 cup brown sugar in a small saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, and cook until thickened. Stir in lemon juice, and remove from heat. Spread the filling over the base, and spread the remaining crumb mixture on top.
Bake in the preheated oven until the top is lightly toasted, 20 to 25 minutes. Cool before cutting into 12 squares.

review.reviewBody: Truly terrible!! What's with the flour? Does anybody test these recipes? I give up on Allrecipes. I'm looking for a recipe to get rid of this one!

Awesome and super delicious! I modified a bit: - added vanilla extract while the dates were reducing - added molasses to the oat crumble for some extra richness Oh. My. Addicted. This is officially the beginning of a problem Iâ€™ll need to address in a while when my pants no longer fit. So delicious.

This recipe is a keeper. My first time making date squares. I use only 1/3 cup Splenda blend (not 1 1/3 cup, as too sweet for us old folks ) and I only had a cup of flour left so I made up the half cup with oats in the blender.

Great recipe to adjust to your own liking. As it is, there's waaay too much crumble (easily use half for 9") and I prefer adding pure vanilla extract instead of lemon. I also like a firmer base so I bake it for about 7 minutes before adding the filling and topping. Delicious!

Can't really rate this recipe as a ran out of flour and substituted 3/4 of the flour required with pancake mix. Maybe if I would have left out the soda (as pancake mix probably has soda in it) it would have been a little more controllable. At 1 point I was going to send my brother to get 2 hockey sticks to beat it back down into the 9Ã—9 pan. It turned out very tasty with 45 mins of cook time. 20 mins on the bottom layer before adding dates, 25 mins at 350 and an extra 10 mins at 325. Yes it turned out OK! Ya know I maybe on to something here. Steve, The Saturday Nite Chef Ps. The wife is out for the evening with the girls so we won't mention anything now will we...
This recipe was perfect. I did use 3 cups of dates because I like lots of dates in my date squares. Delicious. 5 stars
i made the recipe exactly as it is, found it delicious
This is very close to my mom's recipe. The only difference is she only used 1/2 cup butter instead of the 3/4 cup. Love this !
Love these frozenâ€¦.the crumble amountâ€¦Just Rightâ€¦yummmm

I have been craving date squares and am so happy I made them with this recipe. I did run the chopped date/water mix in the moulinex to get more of a thick jam texture. Taste is 5 star, and easy to make. Next time I will cook less as I found the crumble a little hard on top, but base stayed solidly together!. day 2 will soften the top. ðŸ™‚

This is an easy recipe no matter what level of cooking/baking experience you have. These squares are a nice simple dessert just on their own or as finger food for family or group of friends at a function or at the office for a much needed break.

My food scale needed fresh batteries, so I could not weigh my dates. I searched online and found .75 pounds = 3 cups. I believe when a recipe is made, it should have all ingredients in the same measure.

I have made this scrummy recipe several times. It tastes just like the one my mom made when I was growing up. I was so sad when I lost the original recipe but happy when I found this one for date squares. We used to call it Matrimonial Squares.
Just yum. I added some cinnamon and cloves to spice it up. I am so glad I did
I was short about 4oz of dates so I substituted some raisins and dried cranberries. Fantastic! I will definitely be making these again.
Rave reviews on this. I followed the recipe as is and it turned out fantastic.
The baking soda and salt should be decreased.
This has become our favorite Date Square recipe. Just took a pan out of the oven!

These are WONDERFUL!!!! It was like biting into my childhood....I grew up eating ethnic sweets and desserts filled w/dried fruits and nuts. So like others, I made changes too, but, I'm ADDING stars to this recipe review. I dont understand why people take stars away for a recipe they enjoyed but tweaked. TEN STARS here. These were my changes: I used 1/4 cup less brown sugar for the crust, added 1/2 cup chopped pecans, added 1/4 cup more oats (I used quick oats), and added cinnamon and nutmeg, a must! for the filling, do NOT chop dates, there is no need for that extra work. Simply take out the pits, place in a pan and gently warm w/water and 2 tbsp butter, that is key. No more sugar needed. Fold and stir to your preferred consistency, I like my dates soft and spreadable. I used a 9x13 glass pan, coated w/coconut oil, and baked the bottom crust first, 7 min. Then added the date layer and top crust and baked 20 min more. Powdered sugar makes these squares even prettier. I cannot wait to impress my parents. These cookies far exceeded my expectations and I'm so happy I read the reviews. Every baker and every oven is different, but these squares are perfect! Adding to my Christmas cookie list, thank you so much!!!!
All I can say is this is a great recipe! Moist and tasty.
Easy to make , taste great!
The finished product was good but super Sweet! In the future, I'll dial back the sugar be about 1/2 and leave the sugar out of the date mixture completely
I used only 1 cup oats and flour, no sugar in the date mixture and baked first layer prior to layering. So good! Thank you!
fabulous, everyone loved them

Made a few changes to the topping and the filling as I was given my mom's Canadian recipe as well. Something to consider when sugar intake is an issue is use I cup of O.J. in place of sugar in the filling plus 1/2 tsp. vanilla and/or rum extract for flavor. For the topping I added 2 tsp - Cream of Tartar, 1 tsp. , Baking Powder along with softened or melted butter. We grew up having these tasty date bars during the holidays.

I made it according to the recipe and they were awful. I think I know where the recipe and I went wrong.

Far too much sugar in the filling. Cut by half. Far too much flour in the crust. Cut by half. Half cup of sugar and add 1tsp of cinnamon.

Cream the butter and sugar before adding flour and oats.

3 cups of dates and extra water, used full cup of butter for the crumb mix and prebaked the bottom crust 18 minutes to get a nice firm base. This fits a larger pan than just a square baking dish. There's more crust/topping than you think!

Disappointed. I baked the bottom layer first as suggested by previous reviews, and this definitely worked well. The date paste was nice but bland, and the overall slice was dry and very crumbly. I probably won't bother making this again with or without any tweaks. Sorry!
perfect

These are just what I remember from my childhood. I used a larger pan (brownie size) and pre-baked the bottom as some other recipes do for 10 minutes, which made spreading the filling easier. I like lemon juice for the bit of tart and vanilla or almond to add to the complexity of the dates. Used less water and no sugar in dates on the second batch. Delicious. Maybe try more oats and swap out 1/2 the butter for applesauce.

I doubled this recipe and took Lorrie's advice and they came out wonderfully .. My husband loves them although for me .. they were a little on the too sweet side .. I would suggest trying the recipe with less brown sugar as Lorrie suggested.. at least maybe less if you don' t have a big sweet tooth
Loved it!
I didnâ€™t add any sugar with the dates and reduced the sugar in the crumb mixture to 3/4 of a cup. It was sweet enough for me.
Super delicious

OMG are you kidding me these are incredibly delicious. I did not add lemon juice instead I uses almond extract and an oranges juice. Im afraid I will eat the whole thing myself. The kids were turned off by the name, Grandmas date squares is not an appetizing name unless your grandma can make things like these.
Delicious. I doubled and followed advice to bake first layer and omit sugar from date mixture. Sprinkled powdered sugar to serve which made them prettier.

I have made this recipe a few times and my husband is always asking me to make them again. He takes them to his retired fellows' coffee group and they love them. I did make a couple of changes. I feel that the dates are sweet enough without the addition of brown sugar to the date mixture. The other change I made was because I didn't have any lemons, almond flavour or vanilla on hand but I did have some rum which I had used for my Christmas cakes. They were yummy with the rum. I have since made them with the lemon juice and they are still great.

Fantastic date squares. This right here is the REAL DEAL! A pleasant explosion of flavours in your mouth. I've never tasted anything as authentic as this before - certainly restaurant quality. The crust tastes like superior quality shortbread. 

I read some reviews, so I cut the the sugar in the crumb mixture by half, and added only 1 tablespoon of sugar to the date mixture, and it was still sweet enough. 

Thank you for sharing this fabulous recipe Mai. Oh, if your Gramma has more fantastic recipes such as this, please keep them coming. Lol
Made this with my son. It was a bit sticky when we ate it and therefore a bit messy for a toddler. He loves dates though and we are always looking for more to make with dates.
Quite tasty and very easy! Would make again. Might be good with dried apricots, too.
Made it as written, used low salt broth, so had to add some salt at the end. We loved it, will make again.

This is a great recipe. I made it with a very small change in the way I baked it as suggested . I baked the bottom crust first for 10 minutes. It turned out great. 5 stars. We often make minor changes to recipes according to what we have on hand. Also I do understand that people use a recipe as a base and make a number of major changes like reducing fat content or whatever, which turn out really well but then the review and the starts given is no longer the review of this recipe. I suggest to submit a significantly changed recipe in the new ratio of ingredients and new additions and deletions as a new recipe and call it something else: like low fat date square. Or date square number 3 or whatever. Just sayinâ€™

Made this recipe today. It was great. As one reader suggested add another 1/4 c. butter and I did. I did cut back on the brown sugar in the crumb mixture. Only used 3/4 c. then in the filling only used 1/4 c. I found it sweet enough on both parts. Also I added 1 tsp. vanilla. So that is the changes I made. Not many just a tweek. I will make again.
Turned out exactly how my Mum used to make them. Served them to foreign visitors who had never tasted date squares before and they all wanted the recipe.

Omg! These are so delicious, but I did tweak the recipe a little. I used half the brown sugar cause dates are sweet enough. I used 1 cup melted butter. I didnâ€™t bother chopping dates cause they simmered down and I used a fork to mash them a little. Once off the stove I added a splash of vanilla. I sprinkled unsweetened coconut on top of first layer and baked for 15 minutes to crisp up, then put the rest all together. Cooled in fridge before cutting, then fixed myself a nice cup of coffee and sat back and enjoyed. Hope you get to enjoy too cause thereâ€™s no more left here lol

No changes LOVED this recipe â€¦... the hints are also awesome !!!!
I will be making these from now on !!!!!

Easy to follow. Great taste the we remember growing up. The twist was pastry flower so we went with regular all purpose with a bit of cornstarch as sub.

Turn out all good, and kd-approved!
Delicious recipe. I had to add additional water to the dates because it was too difficult to spread over the oatmeal base. Other than that, perfect and delicious! Thanks for sharing this recipe.
Followed the recipe as written and everyone loved them! Definitely will make again!
I actually used TWO square pans for this recipe, which made them thinner and crispier. They freeze well too, and they are not rock hard when taken out of the freezer.
I used steelcut oats, and they worked well!

"Gramma's Date Squares" held together nicely. I subbed the butter with VEGAN BECEL (dairy free) and increased the amount to 1 cup to make the crust hold together better. These were very sweet for my taste, and if I were to make them again strictly for myself I would reduce the sugar by at least half; however, they are perfect for company as is. Thank you Mai Forrester for sharing your recipe.

This was my first time making date squares, so I was a little worried to try it out on company but it was upper easy and tasted just like I remember! Lots of yummy dates and easy to double the batch (which you should, cause theyâ€™re so good).

It was okay... I read the review and made a couple adjustment. I used a whole coupe of butter, baked the bottom crust for 15 minuets first, skipped the extra sugar in the dates, and I added crushed pecans to the top crust for added protein, oh and I used Splenda brown sugar. So I made a lot of changes. Maybe if I would have stocked to the original recipe it would have been better. It was really sweet but was missing something.
Hubby raved!
Love this recipe!
Absolutely love this old school classic date square recipe. Super easy and better than what you expect! Thanks, OP!
Exactly as I remember grandma handing them to me â€” I had a moment. Loved the large flakes of oat; that was the secret! None of that food processor nonsense. Thank you so much!
Beauty recipe. Itâ€™s my grandpaâ€™s favourite and he loved it!!
These were so easy to make, and absolutely delicious!
Yummy
this one was a hit!
I added ground cinnamon to the dates and crumbs. Also tiny bit of ground nutmeg to the crumbs.
I never made these as I have my own recipe. Why would you add 1/3 of cup of brown sugar in the dates, as dates are overly sweet in the first place, that's odd to me.

I used orange juice and orange zest with the dates

I thought the dough part was a bit on the dry side

I will make it again with a few more tweaks including doubling the dates filling
Used Moroccan Vanilla and Rogers Oatmeal porridge which contains flax seed and wheat germ. Froze them in small portions and have them with my coffee in the morning. OMG they are good!

I have always hated date squares, Iâ€™d rather you poke me in the eye than make me eat one. But my hubby loves them. So I finally decided to make some, and use up the pound of dried up dates he bought a year ago and forgot about . Of course they needed to be sampled, and are they ever good! I followed the suggestions from the owner of the bakery that makes these every day! Bravo! Thanks for your hints!
Delicious! Didn't change a thing. First time making them and surprisingly pretty easy!
Followed exactly. Awesome!

Not enough butter to keep the crusts together. I even took it out of the oven early as the top was getting burnt. :/ Temperature was lower as I am higher elevation. But the centre was great, hence the 2 stars!
I have been making this recipe for quite a few years now. Always turns out delicious & holds their form nicely. Itâ€™s a go to recipe for any occasion.
Dates are expensive so I replaced part of the dates with raisins and it came out excellent!
Used a 9 X 12 glass dish and worked out very well
Great recipe. Easy to make. Tastes great.

There are so many issues with this recipe that I couldn't give it a good review. First off, it doesn't say that you should use parchment paper on the bottom. Secondly, it doesn't say to let the date mixture cool before filling it on to the first layer. Thirdly, it doesn't say to cooked the bottom layer for 10 minutes first, but you need to. Fourthly, it doesn't say to put the date mixture in a food processor to chop up that irritating date skin, but it does help quit a bit and improves the texture.

Turned out amazing my husband LOVES a good date cake and this recipe did not disappoint. I made the crust with the full cup of melted butter and I also baked the bottom crust first....very easy to make and turned out DELISH! Will make this over and over again a true keeper.
yummy yummy yummy
This was very good. The only negative was the date layer is too sweet. Next time I will only add a touch of sugar. I also added cinnamon, as it was a bit bland for my taste. Thanks for the recipe.
Good simple recipe. Tasted great. Will add less sugar to date mixture next time.
Just like old fashion date squares that I remember. I did cook the bottom layer first and it made the squares more firm and easier to cut and serve
Simple and delicious! I added lemon juice in date filling along with both vanilla and almond extract (not much). I also used very little sugar in date filling!
Soo good! Husband always asking me to make them.

Outstanding! Wouldn't' change a thing. The only suggestion I'd make is make sure your pan is well greased (I used coconut oil) and pat down well the top layer of oat mixture. Other than that I wouldn't change a thing. This recipe is THE best!

Saddest date squares ever...where are the dates. A real recipe from grandma in my box of classics suggest 2 cups of chopped dates for the same size pan. Hint of Dates is what this recipe should be called.

It was so wonderful , though I made some changes, I used only half cup of sugar in the crust, added full cup of butter, & NO sugar to the date mixture, I added cardimom powder to the dates mixture, I added walnuts to the upper layer of crumble, it took it to another level .. yummy
just like my Grandma's bakeshop

used All Purpose Flour less 2 T and a 1/4 C less brown sugar.
Delicious!
The best date squares I have ever made, everybody loved them!!! This recipe is a keeper.

First time making date squares and this recipe was simple and easy to modify. I reduced the sugar in dough and omitted completely in date/water mix. At first these squares seemed crumbly but hardened and were easy to hold when completely cooled. Highly recommend recipe.
Squares turned out great. Cooked the bottom about 10 min. first and that helped to firm it up. I am a senior and still learning.
No changes and will make again.

Like many other users, I omitted the sugar from the date mixture, used only all-purpose flour, and pre-baked the bottom crust for 8 minutes. Absolutely amazing. Another tip: they MUST cool completely before you eat them. The flavors develop and they will not fall apart. 5 stars.

Doubled it. Froze it (I couldn't resist and kept stealing pieces from the freezer-delicious straight from the freezer). Served it thawed and all loved it. I compromised and used half the amount of brown sugar in with the dates.
out if this World date bars I usually make several batches during the Christmas holiday season. I wish that I could eat them all year round without putting on 20 ponds or so
I have made this 6 times now and is the easiest and so good.

Doubled the recipe and followed Lorrie's suggestions.
These are delicious.
Remind me of my mom's.
Made in a 8x8 pan so that the squares would be thicker. Cooked the bottom layer for about 8 minutes to make it a little crispy before I put the date layer on top of it.
Just Awesome! I love dates and this is one of the best. In fact I took them to a "Pot Luck" for 15 ladies and the hostess told me it was her favorite thing there. Mine too!!!
Love them and so do my friends, thanks for the recipe!
